abstract.t: This document proposes a media type for representing resources and their relations with hyperlinks.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: There is an emergence of non-HTML HTTP applications ("Web APIs") which use hyperlinks to direct clients around their resources.
The JSON Hypertext Application Language (HAL) is a standard which establishes conventions for expressing hypermedia controls, such as links, with JSON .

HAL is a generic media type with which Web APIs can be developed and exposed as series of links. Clients of these APIs can select links by their link relation type and traverse them in order to progress through the application.
HAL's conventions result in a uniform interface for serving and consuming hypermedia, enabling the creation of general-purpose libraries that can be re-used on any API utilising HAL.

The primary design goals of HAL are generality and simplicity. HAL can be applied to many different domains, and imposes the minimal amount of structure necessary to cover the key requirements of a hypermedia Web API.

section.title: Resource Objects
section.t: A Resource Object represents a resource.

It has two reserved properties:
"_links": contains links to other resources. "_embedded": contains embedded resources.
All other properties MUST be valid JSON, and represent the current state of the resource.

section.title: _links
section.t: The reserved "_links" property is OPTIONAL.

It is an object whose property names are link relation types (as defined by ) and values are either a Link Object or an array of Link Objects. The subject resource of these links is the Resource Object of which the containing "_links" object is a property.

section.title: _embedded
section.t: The reserved "_embedded" property is OPTIONAL
It is an object whose property names are link relation types (as defined by ) and values are either a Resource Object or an array of Resource Objects.
Embedded Resources MAY be a full, partial, or inconsistent version of the representation served from the target URI.

section.title: Link Objects
section.t: A Link Object represents a hyperlink from the containing resource to a URI. It has the following properties:

section.title: href
section.t: The "href" property is REQUIRED.
Its value is either a URI or a URI Template .
If the value is a URI Template then the Link Object SHOULD have a "templated" attribute whose value is true.

section.title: templated
section.t: The "templated" property is OPTIONAL.
Its value is boolean and SHOULD be true when the Link Object's "href" property is a URI Template.
Its value SHOULD be considered false if it is undefined or any other value than true.

section.title: type
section.t: The "type" property is OPTIONAL.
Its value is a string used as a hint to indicate the media type expected when dereferencing the target resource.

section.title: deprecation
section.t: The "deprecation" property is OPTIONAL.
Its presence indicates that the link is to be deprecated (i.e. removed) at a future date. Its value is a URL that SHOULD provide further information about the deprecation.

A client SHOULD provide some notification (for example, by logging a warning message) whenever it traverses over a link that has this property. The notification SHOULD include the deprecation property's value so that a client manitainer can easily find information about the deprecation.

section.title: name
section.t: The "name" property is OPTIONAL.
Its value MAY be used as a secondary key for selecting Link Objects which share the same relation type.

section.title: profile
section.t: The "profile" property is OPTIONAL.
Its value is a string which is a URI that hints about the profile (as defined by ) of the target resource.

section.title: title
section.t: The "title" property is OPTIONAL.
Its value is a string and is intended for labelling the link with a human-readable identifier (as defined by ).

section.title: hreflang
section.t: The "hreflang" property is OPTIONAL.
Its value is a string and is intended for indicating the language of the target resource (as defined by ).

Here, the order list document provides a "next" link directing to the next page, and a "find" link containing a URI Template which can be expanded with an 'id' variable to go directly to a specific order.
It also has two embedded resources, "orders". Each of these has its own links to the associated "basket" and "customer" resources, and properties showing their "total", "currency" and "status".

section.title: profile
section.t: The media type identifier application/hal+json MAY also include an additional "profile" parameter (as defined by )
HAL documents that are served with the "profile" parameter still SHOULD include a "profile" link belonging to the root resource.

section.title: Self Link
section.t: Each Resource Object SHOULD contain a 'self' link that corresponds with the IANA registered 'self' relation (as defined by ) whose target is the resource's URI.

section.title: Link relations
section.t: Custom link relation types (Extension Relation Types in ) SHOULD be URIs that when dereferenced in a web browser provide relevant documentation, in the form of an HTML page, about the meaning and/or behaviour of the target Resource. This will improve the discoverability of the API.

The CURIE Syntax MAY be used for brevity for these URIs. CURIEs are established within a HAL document via a set of Link Objects with the relation type "curies" on the root Resource Object. These links contain a URI Template with the token 'rel', and are named via the "name" property.
The above demonstrates the relation "http://docs.acme.com/relations/widgets" being abbreviated to "acme:widgets" via CURIE syntax.

section.title: Hypertext Cache Pattern
section.t: The "hypertext cache pattern" allows servers to use embedded resources to dynamically reduce the number of requests a client makes, improving the efficiency and performance of the application.
Clients MAY be automated for this purpose so that, for any given link relation, they will read from an embedded resource (if present) in preference to traversing a link.
To activate this client behaviour for a given link, servers SHOULD add an embedded resource into the representation with the same relation.
Servers SHOULD NOT entirely "swap out" a link for an embedded resource (or vice versa) because client support for this technique is OPTIONAL.

section.t: A list of libraries is maintained here: http://stateless.co/hal_specification.html

section.title: Why are the reserved properties prefixed with an underscore?
section.t: We elected for a prefix character to minimise risk of collisions with properties that represent the resource's state, and underscore was the character picked.
Another reason for prefixing the reserved properties is to make it visually apparent that the reserved properties are distinct from standard properties belonging to the resource.

section.title: Are all underscore-prefixed properties reserved?
section.t: No, HAL only reserves the names detailed in this specification.

section.title: Why does HAL have no forms?
section.t: Omitting forms from HAL was an intentional design decision that was made to keep it focused on linking for APIs. HAL is therefore a good candidate for use as a base media type on which to build more complex capabilities. An additional media type is planned for the future which will add form-like controls on top of HAL.
